Input.threadtitle: What's wrong with my 'solution'
Input.posts:
Hello :) The harmonization looks ok to me, except for a few things that may sound strange. You double the 5th in both measure 5 and the dominant in measure 8, omitting the leading tone, in this case c#. This is not something you want to omit, it gives the dominant a sense of direction towards the tonic, especially for that time period. Also, there's a doubled 7th (g) in the dominant in measure 3. It does sound mostly ok in this context,  but the resolution of the upper g to an f is weakened if the g is doubled.

Hi Platanias!

Your observation of mistakes in Michele's work is spot on. I think you mean that Michele doubled the 5th in both measure 5 and 8. It's correct that the A, which is the root of the chord and what you mean by the dominant (the 5th scale degree of D major) although she will need to double the A in another voice to compensate for the missing 3rd (C#).

It is also to be noted that the third of this chord, which also happens to be the leading tone of D major, should not be omitted because it gives you the major quality and the identity of the chord. 

As for the last error that you pointed out, you should actually say 'dominant seventh chord' instead of 'dominant' because just using the word 'dominant' means that you are referring to the 5th scale degree of the key. This makes your last paragraph a bit confusing. 

But good job for pointing out the errors!

You double the 5th in both measure 5 and the dominant in measure 8, omitting the leading tone, in this case c#. This is not something you want to omit, it gives the dominant a sense of direction towards the tonic, especially for that time period. Also, there's a doubled 7th (g) in the dominant in measure 3. It does sound mostly ok in this context,  but the resolution of the upper g to an f is weakened if the g is doubled.

Your observation of mistakes in Michele's work is spot on. I think you mean that Michele doubled the 5th in both measure 5 and 8. It's correct that the A, which is the root of the chord and what you mean by the dominant (the 5th scale degree of D major) although she will need to double the A in another voice to compensate for the missing 3rd (C#).

It is also to be noted that the third of this chord, which also happens to be the leading tone of D major, should not be omitted because it gives you the major quality and the identity of the chord. 

As for the last error that you pointed out, you should actually say 'dominant seventh chord' instead of 'dominant' because just using the word 'dominant' means that you are referring to the 5th scale degree of the key. This makes your last paragraph a bit confusing. 

But good job for pointing out the errors!
